Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Intramural Forecasting of Cardiac Electrical Dynamics

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will promote the design of specific methods for preventing and treating arrhythmias and also is an important first step in demonstrating the effectiveness of state estimation techniques for studying cardiac electrical dynamics and other 3D dynamical systems where little or no depth information is available. Cardiac arrhythmias result from the disruption of normal electrical wave propagation in the heart by pre-existing heterogeneous regions or by dynamically induced heterogeneities that develop as a consequence of rapid pacing along with the nonlinear dynamics of the system, both of which can lead to wave breakup. Existing methods for observing electrical waves in three-dimensional experimental heart preparations result in sparse data sets, with either detailed surface observations or data from a small number of points in the interior. Numerical models, on the other hand, are an important method for studying three-dimensional wave propagation, but are only an approximation of the true dynamics. Forecasting methods - previously unused for cardiac electrical models - will be adapted to generate improved estimates of the three-dimensional propagation of cardiac electrical waves. Specifically, data assimilation techniques - developed in the field of numerical weather forecasting - will be applied to combine spatiotemporal observations of voltage on cardiac tissue surfaces with numerical model results to derive a more accurate and realistic three-dimensional quantification of cardiac electrical waves during the initiation and progression of arrhythmias. Using this approach, a more accurate three-dimensional time series that could be used to determine the mechanisms involved in arrhythmia induction and maintenance will be created. Cardiovascular diseases, including cardiac arrhythmias like fibrillation, are the most common cause of death in the industrialized world and have serious health and economic impacts. Advances in treating arrhythmias are hindered in part because of the lack of understanding of their dynamics, which stems from the difficulty of obtaining observations within the thickness of heart tissue. Successful techniques from weather forecasting will be applied to infer the three-dimensional electrical dynamics of cardiac tissue quantitatively using data obtained at the interior and exterior surfaces of the heart.

This research has the potential to elucidate mechanisms underlying cardiac arrhythmias and may lead to new treatment approaches. In addition, the work done as part of this project may contribute to advances in forecasting techniques in a variety of fields where three-dimensional observations are difficult to obtain, including understanding the spread of brain cancer and the dynamics of the deep ocean.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A healthy heart produces a synchronized mechanical contraction by a self-generated electrical signal that propagates through the muscle as a wave. Certain conditions can disturb this normal wave propagation by causing wave breaks that create multiple spiral or scroll waves that repeatedly excite the tissue. Such waves have frequencies several times higher than the heart’s natural pacemaker and therefore become the dominant dynamics of the tissue, resulting in irregular contractions as well. Wave states of this nature correspond to deadly cardiac arrhythmias like tachycardia and fibrillation. Once initiated, spiral or scroll waves occasionally may be stable but more often destabilize by fractionating into new waves. Thus, in most cases, the disorganized spatiotemporal complex activity of fibrillation is associated with at least one and possibly many spiral or scroll waves of electrical activity, which have been observed experimentally at the surface of many preparations including human hearts. Traditional experimental approaches for studying reentrant waves are complemented by mathematical modeling and computer simulation of cardiac electrical wave propagation, which have become important tools for studying cardiac arrhythmias. Such computational studies allow increased access to information and enhanced control over parameters and conditions. With the improved availability of computational resources, the level of sophistication of these simulations has increased as well. It is fairly common to perform simulations of three-dimensional cardiac structures using realistic electrophysiological and anatomical properties. Such studies have contributed to advances in knowledge in understanding in multiple areas, spiral and scroll wave dynamics, defibrillation, and others. However, a fundamental understanding of arrhythmias remains elusive because the dynamics of these waves for the most part remain poorly understood, primarily because of the lack of depth (intramural) information.

 

In this project, we developed a different approach to study and recover the three-dimensional dynamics of reentrant waves in the heart. By applying techniques commonly used in weather forecasting called data assimilation, we combined spatiotemporally sparse observations of a single variable from a particular experiment with predictions from a numerical model to reconstruct the full high-resolution time series of an experiment. To evaluate the performance of our data-assimilation algorithm (which used the Local Ensemble Transform Kalman Filter) in reconstructing such time series, we considered a discordant alternans state in one spatial dimension and scroll waves in three dimensions with model-generated surrogate observations from a numerical experiment. We demonstrated the ability of the system to recover the truth state, including both observed and unobserved variables, using simulated observations from discordant alternans states in 1D and a single scroll wave in 3D with surface-only observations. Where nearby observations were available, the error was reduced below the synthetic observation error, with a smaller reduction with increased distance from observations.

 

To ensure good performance overall, we developed tools for obtaining parameter values to optimize model fit to specific experiments. We showed that we could obtain parameterizations of a flexible phenomenological model of cardiac action potentials in as little as 30 seconds when 13 model parameters were fit simultaneously using a genetic algorithm. We found that our implementation could efficiently obtain model parameterizations in good agreement with the dynamics exhibited by the underlying systems.

 

Real cardiac tissue is unlikely to be described with high accuracy by mathematical models due to errors in model formulation and parameterization as well as intrinsic but poorly described spatial heterogeneity of electrophysiological properties in the heart. Therefore, we also studied our algorithm’s performance under such conditions. We demonstrated that our implementation of data assimilation could provide high-quality reconstructions of one-dimensional electrical wave propagation characterized by significant wavelength oscillations under a wide range of model error conditions, ranging from differences in one or more parameter values to using an entirely different model to generate the truth state. Even when the truth state contained underlying spatial heterogeneity, we showed that using a homogeneous model in the data assimilation algorithm could achieve accurate results and could recover the truth state of observed and unobserved variables at high spatial and temporal resolution with a level of error at or below the level of noise used in generating the observations.

 

Finally we also developed a new experimental system that allowed for the first time confirmation of these intramural scroll waves and their complex dynamics in 3D cardiac tissue. With this system we prove the existence of intramural spiral waves and now can be compared with the numerical models we have also developed in  this project.

 

Overall, we have found that data assimilation is a robust approach for reconstructing high-resolution complex cardiac electrical states corresponding to arrhythmias under a broad range of conditions using only sparse observations and we have also developed experimental tools to allow closer comparison between experiments and simulations of arrhythmias in 3D, which allows better understanding of lethal arrhythmias and future development of better strategies for control and termination of these arrhythmias.
